Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with representation of falcon to right and unidentified elements to left (too eroded); motif possibly stamped rather than incised; pierced through diameter; glaze lost; in pale yellowish paste; very worn out.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Nicholson Museum, University of Sydney. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Falcon is a common theme on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” and appears on various compositions (on productions of the Scarab Factory, see Webb forthcoming). This scaraboid belongs to a type that was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 99, 106-107, type XXVIII A, subtype 149-158). According to a better preserved example, it is possible that the elements to the left of the falcon represent a squatting god or godddess holding a papyrifom sceptre: see Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.700. If this identification is correct, the scaraboid then would belong to Gorton subtype 214-219b of her type XXVIII A. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.026) (phase 3)
